title: A Phase 2b/3, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group, 36-Week, 2-Arm Trial to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of Xanamem® 10 mg Daily in Patients With Mild or Moderate Dementia Due to Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief:
Xanamem® is being developed as a potential treatment for symptomatic, early stages of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).

This XanaMIA Phase 2b/3 study is to investigate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of Xanamem in in mild or moderate dementia due to AD. Trial participants will be randomized to either receive 10mg of Xanamem once daily or a placebo for 36 weeks at a 1:1 ratio in a double-blinded fashion.
drug: Xanamem (emestedastat) — oral small‑molecule 11β‑HSD1 inhibitor, 10 mg once daily
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests Xanamem (an oral small molecule) to alter a biological pathway implicated in AD — brain cortisol production via inhibition of 11β‑HSD1 — with the stated goal of preserving cognition and slowing disease progression, so this fits the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' definition. citeturn1search0turn1search3

Act: Key extracted facts from the description and web sources — (1) Xanamem's nonproprietary name is emestedastat and it is a small‑molecule drug. citeturn1search0 (2) Its mechanism is inhibition of 11β‑hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (11β‑HSD1) to reduce intracellular/brain cortisol. citeturn1search3turn1search0 (3) The XanaMIA Phase 2b/3 trial is a 36‑week, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of Xanamem 10 mg once daily vs placebo in mild–moderate AD, assessing cognition, function and disease progression. citeturn0search1turn0search4 (4) The program explicitly aims to assess effects on disease course (slowing progression) and cognition, not solely symptomatic neuropsychiatric effects. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Reflect: Classification check — Xanamem is not a biologic (it is a small molecule) and is intended to modify a biologically relevant disease pathway (brain cortisol synthesis) with the aim of altering progression and cognition, so 'disease‑targeted small molecule' is the best fit. There is low ambiguity: although the drug also showed effects in depression and on cognitive symptoms (so has symptomatic effects), its mechanism and trial objectives are disease‑pathway directed rather than purely symptomatic cognitive enhancement or neuropsychiatric symptom management. citeturn1search3turn0search1

Web search results cited (short): (1) Actinogen announcement describing Xanamem (emestedastat) and its mechanism (11β‑HSD1 inhibitor). citeturn1search0 (2) Clinical pharmacology review describing emestedastat pharmacology and 11β‑HSD1 PET/PK/PD data. citeturn1search3 (3) PR/press items describing the XanaMIA Phase 2b/3 36‑week trial, 10 mg daily vs placebo, endpoints (cognition, CDR‑SB) and intent to assess disease progression. citeturn0search1turn0search4 (4) Trial progress / interim analysis and extension details. citeturn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial drug (Xanamem/emestedastat) inhibits 11β‑HSD1 to reduce intracellular/brain cortisol production — a modulation of a hormone (glucocorticoid) pathway implicated in AD, so the primary biological focus is on hormonal regulation rather than amyloid, tau, inflammation, etc.

Act: Extracted facts — (1) Xanamem (emestedastat) is an oral small‑molecule 11β‑HSD1 inhibitor given 10 mg once daily. (2) Its mechanism is intended to reduce brain/cellular cortisol by blocking 11β‑hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1. (3) The trial (XanaMIA Phase 2b/3) aims to preserve cognition and slow disease progression in mild–moderate AD, i.e., to modify a disease‑relevant hormonal pathway. Based on these, the best CADRO match is L) Growth Factors and Hormones.

Reflect: Verification — 11β‑HSD1 directly regulates local glucocorticoid (cortisol) activation, which is a hormonal mechanism; although metabolic or stress‑related pathways could be considered, the intervention is most specifically a hormone‑modulating strategy, so L) Growth Factors and Hormones is the most specific and appropriate CADRO category. There is low ambiguity and no indication of multi‑target or purely diagnostic/non‑therapeutic focus.

Web search results cited (short, as provided): (1) Actinogen announcement describing Xanamem (emestedastat) and its mechanism (11β‑HSD1 inhibitor). (2) Clinical pharmacology review describing emestedastat pharmacology and 11β‑HSD1 PET/PK/PD data. (3) PR/press items describing the XanaMIA Phase 2b/3 36‑week trial, 10 mg daily vs placebo, endpoints (cognition, CDR‑SB) and intent to assess disease progression. (4) Trial progress / interim analysis and extension details.
